Parallel

ä¸¦åˆ—ã¨ã¯ã€Œè¤‡æ•°ã®ã‚¿ã‚¹ã‚¯ãŒï¼Œç‰©ç†çš„ã«ï¼ŒåŒæ™‚ã«å‡¦ç†ã•ã‚Œã¦ã„ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã€

å…·ä½“çš„ã«ã¯ãƒãƒ«ãƒã‚³ã‚¢ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ãƒƒã‚µãŒï¼Œæ­è¼‰ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹è¤‡æ•°ã®ãƒ—ãƒ­ã‚»ãƒƒã‚µã‚’ã¡ã‚ƒã‚“ã¨ä½¿ã„åˆ‡ã£ã¦æ¼”ç®—ã‚’ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹æ§˜ã¯ï¼Œä¸¦åˆ—ã¨ã„ã†è¨€è‘‰ã§å½¢å®¹ã§ãã‚‹ï¼

**ã€Œè¤‡æ•°äººãŒåŒæ™‚ã«ï¼Œãã‚Œãã‚Œã®ä»•äº‹ã‚’é€²ã‚ã¦ã„ã‚‹æ§˜ã€**ãŒä¸¦åˆ—ï¼

ã¡ãªã¿ã«ï¼Œã€Œä¸¦åˆ—ã§ã‚ã‚Œã°å¸¸ã«ä¸¦è¡Œã§ã‚ã‚‹ã€ã¨ã„ã†ä¸»å¼µã‚‚ã‚ã‚‹ã‚‰ã—ã„ï¼ã€Œè¤‡æ•°äººãŒåŒæ™‚ã«ï¼Œãã‚Œãã‚Œã®ä»•äº‹ã‚’é€²ã‚ã¦ã„ã‚‹æ§˜ã€ã¯å´ã‹ã‚‰è¦‹ã‚‹ã¨ã€Œã„ã‚ã‚“ãªä»•äº‹ã‚’åŒæ™‚ã«é€²ã‚ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã€ã‚ˆã†ã«è¦‹ãˆã‚‹ã‹ã‚‰ï¼Œç¢ºã‹ã«ãã†ã‹ã‚‚ã—ã‚Œãªã„ï¼

Rob Pikeå…ˆç”Ÿã«ã‚ˆã‚Œã°…

Concurrency is about dealing with lots of things at once.

Parallelism is about doing lots of things at once.

Not the same, but related.

Concurrency is about structure, parallelism is about execution.

Concurrency provides a way to structure a solution to solve a problem that may (but not necessarily) be parallelizable.

ãªã‚‹ã»ã©

çµå±€ãªã‚“ã ã£ã¦ã°ã‚ˆ…

  • Concurrency is a way of structuring your program to make it easy to understand and scalable

  • and Parallelism is simply the execution of multiple goroutine in parallel

ref

  • Concurrency is not Parallelism

item.title: Emulator v.s. Simulator
item.description:
ã‚ã‚‹äººã«ã‚ˆã‚Œã°…

Simulation = For analysis and study

Emulation = For usage as a substitute

A simulator is an environment which models but an emulator is one that replicates the usage as on the original device or system.

Simulator mimics the activity of something that it is simulating. It “appears” (a lot can go with this “appears”, depending on the context) to be the same as the thing being simulated. For example the flight simulator “appears” to be a real flight to the user, although it does not transport you from one place to another.

Emulator, on the other hand, actually “does” what the thing being emulated does, and in doing so it too “appears to be doing the same thing”. An emulator may use different set of protocols for mimicking the thing being emulated, but the result/outcome is always the same as the original object. For example, EMU8086 emulates the 8086 microprocessor on your computer, which obviously is not running on 8086 (= different protocols), but the output it gives is what a real 8086 would give.

ã¾ãŸåˆ¥ã®äººã«ã‚ˆã‚Œã°…

  1. Simulator is broader than Emulator
  1. Simulator tends to imitate/model more global processes/things in general with ability to narrow the imitation down (e.g. capacitor simulator with presets representing some known models)
  1. Emulator tends to imitate certain hardware devices with certain specification, known characteristics and properties (e.g. SNES emulator, Intel 8087 or Roland TB-303)

èªæºã‚’è¾¿ã‚‹ã¨…

  • emulate is “to be equal” (looks like more aggressive and straightforward - rivalry)
  • simulate is “to be similar” (looks like more sly and tricky - imitation)

æ—¥æœ¬èªã ã¨…

  • Emulation: ï¼ˆä»£æ›¿å¯èƒ½ãªãƒ¬ãƒ™ãƒ«ã§ã®ï¼‰æ¨¡å€£
  • Simulation: æ¨¡æ“¬

ã‹ãªï¼ŸğŸ¤”

Reference

  • Simulator or Emulator? What is the difference?
